title: Vehicle prices will rise initially, then gradually decrease: President
byline: President Anura Kumara Dissanayaka said yesterday that though there will be a price increase upon resuming vehicle imports in February, after a five-year pause, the prices will gradually decrease depending on market behaviour.

title: Coconut chamber urges govt. to import 200 Mn nuts to prevent crisis
byline: The Ceylon Chamber of Coconut Industries (CCCI), the umbrella organisation for Sri Lanka’s coconut industry, yesterday urged the government to expedite the proposal to import 200 million nuts urgently to avert a looming dual crisis.

title: Bishop asks Trump to show mercy to LGBT people and migrants
byline: The direct appeal to President Trump at the start of the first full day of his presidency was a remarkable moment at a National Cathedral event that traditionally has not been political.

title: President says no personal revenge in reclaiming former presidents’ residences
byline: The issue of handing over the Presidential residence came to the forefront when the government started fulfilling its election promises. However, this is not a personal issue or an act of revenge against anyone, President Anura Kumara Dissanayaka said in a television programme last night.

title: Over 12,000 traffic violations identified via CCTV in Colombo
byline: Since February last year, a total of 12,918 motorists have been identified for violating traffic rules through the CCTV system in Colombo.

title: December inflation records 2% YoY dip, extending deflationary trend to fourth consecutive month
byline: Sri Lanka’s National Consumer Price Index (NCPI) recorded a 2.0 percent year-on-year decline in December 2024, extending the deflationary trend to its fourth consecutive month.

title: Tourist arrivals cross 100,000 mark within first 2 weeks of January
byline: Tourist arrival crossed the 100,000 mark within the first two weeks of January, recording a Year-on-Year (YoY) increase of 22 percent.

title: PTA will be repealed, new legislation will be introduced instead: Justice Minister
byline: The Prevention of Terrorism Act (PTA) will be repealed and a new legislation will be introduced in place of it, Justice Minister Harshana Nanayakkara told Parliament today.

title: South Korea’s birthrate set to rise for the first time in nine years
byline: South Korea’s birthrate is set to show a rise in 2024 for the first time in nine years, following a rebound in marriages that were delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Children to name Ridiyagama lion cubs: Visit park on Feb 4 to see them
byline: Children will have the opportunity to suggest names to six newly born lion cubs at the Ridiyagama Safari Park in Hambantota, Assistant Director of the park Hemantha Samarasekera said.

title: Ex-policeman arrested over abduction of woman in viral video
byline: A former police officer has been arrested over a viral video showing a woman being forcibly abducted by two individuals, one of whom was dressed as a police officer.

title: Veteran singer Anil Bharathi passes away
byline: Veteran singer Anil Bharathi has passed away at the age of 75, according to family sources.

title: Doctor shouting at patients caught on camera
byline: A video is going viral on social media showing a female doctor rudely shouting at patients.

title: Customs declines responsibility for red-flagged 323 containers released by Govt
byline: The Customs Trade Union Alliance (CTUA) today announced that it will not take the responsibility for the goods contained in the 323 containers which were flagged red by the computer system, but cleared and released by the government recently.

title: EC debunks EU recommendation on voter education
byline: In reference to one of the key recommendations made in the final report of the European Union Election Observation Mission on the Presidential Election, which highlighted that voter education on the use of preferential voting was insufficient, the Elections Commission (EC) stated that they did their best to educate voters on preferential voting.

title: Government decides to go ahead with power tariff reduction
byline: The Government has decided to go ahead with the power tarrif reduction recommended by the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL), ruling party MP Samanmalee Gunasinghe informed Parliament today.

title: President hints at positive development on Easter Sunday probe
byline: The progress of the ongoing investigations into the Easter Sunday carnage will be announced in about a week, says President Anura Kumara Dissanayaka.

title: Public urinates on parapet walls in Dehiwala Mount Lavinia: MP Samanmalee
byline: Almost all parapet walls in the Dehiwala-Mount Lavinia area have been spoiled as people urinate on them, government MP Samanmalee Gunasinghe told Parliament today.

title: Abduction of schoolgirl: Actg. OIC Daulagala Police interdicted
byline: The Actg, OIC Daulagala police has been interdicted and two other officers transferred for failing to take prompt action regarding the recent abduction of the schoolgirl.

title: Govt. increases compensation for weather-related deaths to Rs. 1 Mn
byline: The government has approved a significant increase in compensation for lives lost due to the prevailing severe weather, raising the amount from Rs. 250,000 to Rs. 1 million, the Ministry of Defence said.

title: Committee appointed to revise SOP to foreign research vessels
byline: A committee chaired by Foreign Minister Vijitha Herath has been formed to amend the existing Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for granting diplomatic clearance to foreign warships, military aircraft and research vessels in Sri Lanka.

title: Foreign fuel distributors in dilemma
byline: The US-based petroleum products distributor ‘Shell-RM Parks’ which entered Sri Lanka’s retail market by running dealer-operated filling stations is now involved in a dilemma since some dealers are non-cooperative, and the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPP ) finds it impossible to intervene due to loopholes in the agreement signed during the time of former Minister Kanchana Wijesekera, an official said.

title: Sonal Dinusha set to be in Sri Lanka squad
byline: Sri Lanka’s 24-year-old Sonal Dinusha is in line for the call up for the 17-member squad for the Test series against Australia, it is learnt. According to the well-placed sources close to the selectors, the 24-yearbowling all rounder is likely to have been asked to join the preparatory camp to begin today.

title: What happened to forensic audit into e-Visa scam? Champika Ranawaka asks Vijitha Herath
byline: United Republican Front (URF) leader Patali Champika Ranawaka queried about the fate of forensic audit regarding the e-Visa scam, as promised by Foreign Affairs Minister Vijitha Herath.

title: UK PM reaffirms winning justice for Sri Lankan Tamil victims
byline: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer has reaffirmed his commitment in addressing justice and accountability of reconciliation in Sri Lanka and the issues faced by Tamils, admiring the UK Tamil community’s contribution to British society, the Daily Mirror learns.

title: Sri Lanka rugby legend Yu Cey Chang is no more
byline: Sri Lanka’s rugby community mourned the passing of a stalwart of the game Yu Cey Chang whose funeral took place today just hours after he breathed his last. He was 82 at the time of his death.

title: Police arrest 2,728 within 10 days during island-wide crime, drugs operation
byline: Sri Lanka Police arrested 2,728 suspects, including over 150 directly involved in drug trafficking and crimes, during a special operation that began on January 12.

title: Releasing of red-tagged containers to be probed: Deputy Minister
byline: While admitting that 323 containers with red tags have been released through the green channel, Deputy Minister of Finance said today that an investigation will be launched into the incident.

title: Rice mills will be taken under army’s control, if they fail to agree to government mechanism: President
byline: Claiming that no one will be allowed to sell rice beyond the control price, President Anura Kumara Dissanayake said rice mills will be taken under army control if they fail to agree to the mechanism of the government.
